awd_titl_txt: Methods for improved size resolution for particle impactors
awd_abstract_narration:
The presence of particles in the atmosphere has a significant impact on human health.  Continued exposure to pollutant particles contributes to ailments such as asthma, lung cancer, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD).  In addition, studies have shown that emergency room visits and mortality rates are correlated to the level of particulate pollution in the air on that day.  The size of a particle has a significant effect on where it deposits in the lung and therefore on its health impact.  For example, micron scale particles are very effective at depositing in the deepest recesses of the lung, while larger particles tend to deposit in the upper bronchial tubes and in the pharynx.  Recently, animal studies have shown that nanometer sized particles can translocate from the lungs to other organs, including the brain.  Many studies have been conducted which measure the number and size distribution of particles in the atmosphere and in industrial work environments, with the goal of understanding the formation and removal of particles from the air.  Particle counters, instruments which size and count particles for diameters ranging from a few nanometers to hundreds of microns, are an indispensable tool in these studies.  Particle counters exist which have good size resolution over this range of particle diameters. However, this type of counter is expensive, fragile, and barely portable, as they use lasers, vacuum chambers, and high voltage.  A cheaper, more robust, and highly portable alternative is a device called a cascade impactor. Unfortunately, these devices have poor particle diameter resolution, a significant problem given the effect of particle diameter on human health.  This research takes advantage of newly discovered physics of particles in impactors to dramatically extend their sizing capabilities.  Successful completion of this research will enable studies that would not otherwise be possible.  This research therefore serves as a force multiplier, enabling particle scientists and epidemiologists to dramatically extend their capabilities.  Additionally, this work will result in the training of at least one graduate student and several undergraduates in the field of particle science, an important discipline that is typically not part of graduate or undergraduate engineering curricula.

Impactor cascades are used to size and count particles in air for a large range of applications, including epidemiological studies, monitoring of worker exposure in industries such as mining and construction, and studies of atmospheric pollution.  While these devices can sense particles down to diameters as small as 10 nm, their diameter resolution is poor.  Commercially available impactor cascades yield particle size distributions (PSDs) having at most 13 bins.  This research consists of a set of computational simulations and experiments that will demonstrate how particles can be size-segregated within a single impactor stage, thereby dramatically increasing the diameter resolution of the PSDs that can be obtained from impactor cascades.  Preliminary research by the principal investigator has shown that relatively minor modifications of the impactor geometry can cause particles captured by an impactor plate to be distributed in the radial direction of the plate according to their diameter.  That is, larger diameter particles are located near the center of the plate and smaller ones near the periphery.  This size segregation of particles allows for a virtually unlimited number of bins in PSDs obtained from impactor cascades.  These preliminary results were obtained for micron scale particles.  The research will explore further variations of the impactor geometry which can maximize this effect and then demonstrate its efficacy down to diameters as small as 10 nm.  The principal investigator will recruit female and underrepresented minority graduate students to participate in this research, and outreach to high school students will be part of the project.

por.por_cntn:
This long-term goal of this project was to develop a way to improve the performance of a class of devices called impactors.  Impactors are used to measure the diameter of aerosols (small particles and/or drops) in the air.  These devices are very useful because they are robust and relatively cheap, in contrast to other devices that can be fragile and expensive.  Hence, they can be effectively used in field studies, or in challenging environments such as certain industrial settings or underground mines, for example.  Unfortunately, impactors suffer from a lack of sizing resolution.  This means that an impactor might have difficulty detecting the difference between a particle having a diameter of 1.0 microns and one having a diameter of 1.1 microns.  The goal of this work was to develop the scientific underpinnings to allow impactors to have much higher resolution and to work at the nanoscale. 

 

Impactors operate by directing a jet of the air to be measured at a plate.  The jet  is typically located about one nozzle diameter (W) away from the plate.  The distance from the nozzle to the plate is given the variable S.  Hence, impactors typically operate with S/W = 1.  When operated in this way, particles larger than a certain cutoff diameter hit the plate, while those smaller than the cutoff diameter flow around the plate to the next impactor which would have a different nozzle diameter.  The particles impacting the plate form a disc shaped pattern and by measuring the mass of what is deposited, the number of particles having a specific diameter range can be obtained.  Hence, the number of different particle diameters that can be measured (diameter bins) is equal to the number of individual impactors in a typical impactor cascade.  This number typicially ranges from five to ten impactors.  This is not desirable, as one would prefer to have, say, 100 bins, not five to ten. 

 

In our earlier work we showed that if S/W is much smaller, less than 0.1, two interesting things happen.  First, the impaction pattern is a ring, not a disc.  Secondly, the radial location of deposition is related to the particle diameter.  This is exciting because it means that with a single impactor, multiple particle diameters can be measured.  So, if one could, for example, measure ten different particle diameters on a single impactor, then a ten impactor cascade could measure 100 different particle diameters.  However to actually do this would require developing a scientific understanding of what controls where particle diameters deposit and what factors affect that location.  This was what was done in this projectd. 

 

Things that affect the deposition location (the diameter of the ring formed for a given particle diameter) of a particle in a low S/W impactor includes S/W itself.  In the attached figure, rings are shown for different particle diameters and different S/W, a major result from this work.  This work also determined how relative humidity plays a role in particle impact and the use of the ideas presented above. 

 

Nanoparticles have become an increasingly important area of scientific study and hence the ability to measure the size and number of nanoparticles in an air sample has become important.  This is especially true since we are only beginning to understand the impacts that nanoparticles can have on the health of humans.  Accordingly, an important part of this work was to demonstrate that the above method worked for particles at the nanoscale.  This was challenging since nanoparticles are too small to be seen with typical imaging systems (e.g. an image like that attached could not be obtained for 100nm particles) and so scanning electron microscope (SEM) imagery had to be obtained to characterize the ring diameter for each nanoparticle diameter explored.  This was achieved, and it was shown that the above method works for nanoparticles as well. 

 

The research conducted for this project opens the door for instrumentation developers to create impactors having a far higher diameter resolution than those that exist on the market today.  This would enable development of impactors that are still cheap, but that can obtain high resolution measurements of aerosols in the air.
